review.title: M2D: Monolog to Dialog Generation for Conversational Story Telling
review.abstract: Storytelling serves many different social functions, e.g. stories are used to persuade, share troubles, establish shared values, learn social behaviors, and entertain. Moreover, stories are often told conversationally through dialog, and previous work suggests that information provided dialogically is more engaging than when provided in monolog. In this paper, we present algorithms for converting a deep representation of a story into a dialogic storytelling, that can vary aspects of the telling, including the personality of the storytellers. We conduct several experiments to test whether dialogic storytellings are more engaging, and whether automatically generated variants in linguistic form that correspond to personality differences can be recognized in an extended storytelling dialog.

sections.heading: 4 Evaluation Experiments
sections.text: We assume that H1 is based on previous experimental work, and are testing H2 and H3. Our experiments aim to (1) determine whether and to what extent the m2d engine produces natural dialogues; (2) determine how the use of different parameters affects the user's engagement with the history and perception of the naturalness of the dialogue; and (3) test whether users perceive personality differences generated by previous work. All experimental participants are pre-qualified Amazon Mechanical Turkers to guarantee that they make detailed and thoughtful comments.

sections.heading: 4.1 M2D-EST vs. -Basic vs. -Chatty
sections.text: A paired t-test comparing m2d-chatty with m2d-est shows that the increase in the number of suitable characteristics makes the dialogue more engaging (p =.04, df = 9). However, there are no statistically significant differences between m2d-basic and m2d-est or between m2d-basic and m2d-chatty. Comments from Turks suggest that the m2d-chatty speakers have more personality because they use many different pragmatic markers, such as questions and other dialogically oriented characteristics. The perception of naturalness through the same set of dialogical stories is shown in Figure 6. It shows that m2d-basic was rated higher than m2d-est, and their paired t-t-test shows that m2d-basic (including pronouns and aggregation) has a positive influence on the naturalness of a dialogue (0.0d = 0.0d = 0.0d = 0.0d = basic chatty = other 2d is noted) where m2d is frequently used.

sections.heading: 5 Discussion and Future Work
sections.text: We suspect that dialogical storytelling can elicit more engagement from the listener, and that the ability to present a story as a dialogue will have many practical applications (e.g. with gestures [10]. We also suspect that the expression of personality in storytelling will be useful and will show how it is possible to do this in the experiments presented here. We describe an initial system that can translate a monological deep syntactic structure into many different dialogical renderings. We evaluated different versions of our m2d system, and the results suggest that engagement in dialogical storytelling increases proportionally with the density of interactive features.
